cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 133 (Friday, August 4, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. NEGUSE:H.R. 5149.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8The single subject of this legislation is:To direct the Secretary of Defense to carTy out a pilotprogram to provide stipends to certain members separatingfrom the Armed Forces.[Page H4166]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

cdata.text: This bill requires the Department of Defense (DOD) to implement a pilot program to provide stipends to certain individuals who DOD determines will experience financial hardship during the first 120 days following separation from the Armed Forces. An individual must have separated from the Armed Forces under honorable conditions and served at least four years to be eligible for a stipend.

bill.title: To direct the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program to provide stipends to certain members separating from the Armed Forces.

item.title: To direct the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program to provide stipends to certain members separating from the Armed Forces.
To direct the Secretary of Defense to carry out a pilot program to provide stipends to certain members separating from the Armed Forces.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
